thread.title: United Nations to investigate 'extreme poverty' in Newcastle amid benefit and council cuts

author: Jonathan Walker
title: United Nations to investigate 'extreme poverty' in Newcastle amid benefit and council cuts
text:
News United Nations to investigate 'extreme poverty' in Newcastle amid benefit and council cuts An inquiry chose Newcastle as to investigate 'extreme poverty' connected to benefit cuts and cuts to the local council Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Get daily updates directly to your inbox Subscribe Thank you for subscribing We have more newsletters Show me See our privacy notice Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email
A United Nations investigator leading an inquiry into poverty is to visit Newcastle to examine the impact of austerity.
Australian academic Philip Alston, the UN Special Rapporteur on “extreme poverty”, chose Newcastle along with Belfast, Bristol, Cardiff, Edinburgh, Essex, Glasgow, Jaywick and London as the focus of his inquiry.
It comes after Newcastle City Council and academics at Newcastle University urged him to visit the city.
They sent him a report which said the North East is one of the UK regions with the highest number of deprived areas.
They said: “Welfare reforms have hit hardest where reliance on benefits has been greatest and the most affected places are older industrial areas, many of which are located in the North East of England.
“These places have also been among the most affected in terms of cuts to local government, reducing statutory funding to voluntary and community sector bodies.” Read More Almost 23,000 food parcels handed out in the North East over six months
Child poverty is higher in Newcastle than many other places, the report’s authors said.
They said: “Levels of child poverty in Newcastle are above the national average: 54,580 dependent children until the age of 20 (29.1%) live in low-income families, compared to 19.9% in England.”
And they also said there were high levels of inequality even within Newcastle, saying: “There is a widening gap between the city’s highest and lowest earners.
The paper was written by academics in Newcastle University’s Institute of Health and Society, and endorsed by Newcastle City Council. West End Food Bank in Newcastle. Pictured from left are John Robson and Craig Nielsen (Image: ncjMedia)
During his two-week visit to the UK, the Special Rapporteur will meet with Government and council officials to discuss efforts to eradicate poverty. He will also meet with people affected by poverty to hear about their experiences.
Issues he will look at include the introduction of Universal Credit, child poverty and the implications of Brexit on poverty.
He will examine the effects of so-called austerity measures, including changes to benefits and to local government funding. Read More No heating and going without food: The harsh reality families face due to tough benefits cap
And he will look at the impact of providing government services online, including making access to benefits such as Universal Credit “digital by default”. Some critics say this has contributed to problems with the new benefit system, because some people receiving Universal Credit don’t have access to the internet.
Mr Alston said: “The United Kingdom is one of the richest countries in the world, but millions of people are still living in poverty there. Read More
